  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The design features elongated triangles at both ends of the kain panjang
 against a dark background with rosette patterns. The middle section of the kain panjang is decorated with repeated floral bouquets against a cream background. There are no signatures on this kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) flower (motif) foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  subject_terms_4: Kain panjang

  sgcool_label_text: The design structure of this kain panjang is typical of north coast batik from the same period
 in particular the split kepalas (or elongated triangles) on both ends of the batik.  Bouquets of flowers embellish the main design field (badan) of the cloth
 creating a wallpaper effect.  They are reminiscent of the “wallpaper” patterns that are stamped on wallpaper with the wooden blocks.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942)
 the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time
 and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers
 centipedes and cloud motifs
 which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java
 before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The design features elongated triangles at both ends of the kain panjang, against a dark background with rosette patterns. The middle section of the kain panjang is decorated with repeated floral bouquets against a cream background. There are no signatures on this kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The design structure of this kain panjang is typical of north coast batik from the same period, in particular the split kepalas (or elongated triangles) on both ends of the batik.  Bouquets of flowers embellish the main design field (badan) of the cloth, creating a wallpaper effect.  They are reminiscent of the “wallpaper” patterns that are stamped on wallpaper with the wooden blocks.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.
